Understate: The claim understates the amount of student debt at the University of Texas by only mentioning the median debt of $20,755, which means that half of the graduates had more debt than that.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it only provides one figure for the median debt and does not provide any additional data or sources to back up the claim of being "one of the lowest debts across the nation."
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the median debt of $20,755 for UT graduates is representative of all undergraduate students at the University of Texas, which may not be accurate.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for the low median debt at the University of Texas, such as a higher proportion of students receiving financial aid or scholarships compared to other universities.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by using a 12-year median debt figure, which may not accurately represent the current debt situation for UT graduates.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that some graduates at the University of Texas have significantly higher levels of debt, with 10% owing $42,051 or more.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the low level of student debt at the University of Texas by not considering all graduates or loan recipients and only focusing on a specific group of first-time students on a UT campus.
